member_organisations:
www.veterinaryireland.ie  
Veterinary Ireland has six Interest Groups: 
 
Food Animal - Representing those Veterinary Practitioners providing veterinary services to the owners/ keepers of cattle (dairy and Beef), sheep, pigs, aquaculture, and poultry. 
 
Veterinary Ireland Companion Animal Society (VICAS)Representing those Veterinary Practitioners providing veterinary services to the owners/keepers of dogs, cats, and other companion animals. 
 
Equine 
Representing those Veterinary Practitioners providing veterinary services to the owners/keepers of equidae. 
 
Local Authority 
Representing those Veterinary Practitioners providing veterinary services on behalf of Irish Local Authorities. 
 
State Sector 
Representing those Veterinary Practitioners providing veterinary services on behalf of State Agencies. 
 
Education, Research & Industry (ERI) 
Representing those Veterinary Practitioners providing veterinary services on behalf of Education, Research and Industry organisations.
fields_of_interest: Agriculture, Trade, Competition, International co-operation and development, Education and training, Environment, Youth, Maritime affairs and fisheries, Regional Policy, Research and innovation, External Relations, Trans-European Networks, Public Health, Food Safety

membership:
Veterinary Ireland is an active participatory Member of the Federation of Veterinarians of Europe (FVE) and its Sections (UEVP and EVERI) as well as species specific veterinary organisations, FECAVA (Companion Animals) and FEEVA (Equine). 
 
FVE:  
http://www.fve.org/ 
 
UEVP:  
http://www.fve.org/about_fve/sections/UEVP.php 
 
EVERI: 
http://www.fve.org/about_fve/sections/EVERI.php 
 
FECAVA:  
http://www.fecava.org/ 
 
FEEVA: 
http://www.fve.org/about_fve/organisations.php
goals__remit:
The role of Veterinary Ireland is to represent veterinary practitioners in Ireland and to facilitate the veterinary profession in its commitment to improving the health and welfare of the animals under its care, to protecting public health and to serving the changing needs of its clients and the community through effective and innovative leadership. 
 
PRINCIPAL OBJECTS  
The objects of the Organisation are: 
 
To secure the organisation of persons engaged or associated with the business, practice, teaching or study of veterinary medicine. 
 
To promote the science of veterinary medicine and the quality of animal and public health in various ways including the provision of opportunities for the continuing professional development of members. 
 
To procure and ensure the maintenance of just and reasonable terms of employment, and proper remuneration of its members and generally promote the honour and interest of the veterinary profession. 
 
To regulate the relations between members and employers, between members and members, and between employers and employees, or to impose restrictive conditions on the conduct of the members and to provide benefits to members.  The term ‘employer’ includes all parties who shall offer to engage, employ or retain by any means whatsoever the professional services of a member of the Organisation in relation to the practice of veterinary medicine or any allied practice or discipline whether same is on their own behalf or as agent(s) or representative(s) for third parties. 
 
To negotiate and settle all matters pertaining to the practice of veterinary medicine with all parties on behalf of the members and to avail of any lawful means in pursuit of the same. 
 
To promote or oppose legislation pertaining to the practice of veterinary medicine or related disciplines and to co-operate with other bodies where necessary or expedient to do so and to seek the introduction of legislation to advance the interests of the Organisation as a Union and its members.  
 
To maintain and develop its position as the national representative veterinary organisation and, through its Interest Groups, continue to represent the profession at European and international levels. 
 
To continue to develop coherent policies on veterinary issues and to defend at all times the independence of the members. 
 
To negotiate with and to become affiliated to or associated with Associations, Corporate Bodies, Societies, Trade Unions or other bodies concerned with matters of interest to the Organisation as a Union and/or its members. 
 
To do all such other objects permissible to a Trade Union under the Trade Union Acts. 
 
To comply with all legal requirements under the Trade Union Acts.
